description: Alteration of earlier fixen, from Middle English fixen, either from Old English *fyxen, from Proto-West Germanic *fuhsini; synchronically analyzable as fox +‎ -en, the voiced v- being from the Southern dialectal forms of Middle English; or from the Old English adjective fyxen (“of the fox”), as in the phrase fixen hȳd (“fox skin”; compare Middle English foxen fox).

entries.meaning: A malicious, quarrelsome or temperamental woman.
examples: […]  and if Solomon was as wise as he is reputed to be, I feel sure that when he compared a contentious woman to a continual dripping on a very rainy day, he had not a vixen in his eye–a fury with long nails, acrid and selfish.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) A racy or salacious woman who is sexually attractive.
(colloquial) A wife who has sex with other men with her husband's consent.
examples: The stag gets a thrill from watching his vixen have sex with another man.
